channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Rubio says the U.S. doesn’t need Venezuelan oil but seeks to deny adversaries control over it—and doesn’t rule out occupying the country
item.description: "What we're not going to allow is for the oil industry in Venezuela to be controlled by adversaries of the United States."

item.title: Rubio Stresses U.S. Plan to Coerce Venezuela Rather Than Govern It
item.description: The secretary of state said that a military “quarantine” on some oil exports would stay in place to put pressure on the country’s acting leadership.

item.title: The Venezuela I Know
item.description: Many are celebrating the ouster of a brutal dictator, but the Maduro regime may survive the loss of Maduro.

item.title: Venezuela’s capital Caracas is unusually quiet with stores and gas stations closed, a day after Maduro was deposed by U.S.
item.description: A day before, lines wound through stores and outside gas stations as uncertain Venezuelans stocked up on goods in case turmoil broke out.

item.title: What is the Monroe Doctrine? Here’s how it has shaped U.S. foreign policy for two centuries, including Trump’s ouster of Maduro
item.description: It was intended to ward off European colonization or other interference in the Western Hemisphere. In return, the U.S. also agreed to stay out of Euro...

item.title: Iran Faces Economic Challenges and Military Threats
item.description: Officials said that leaders were in survival mode amid anti-government protests and the prospect of again coming into the cross hairs of Israel and th...

item.title: The U.S. military emerged as a big winner after Maduro’s capture. The other sensation is this Nike outfit
item.description: "Maduro looks like a man who was on Xmas break and wearing his Nike Tech Fleece for a third straight day."

item.title: The U.S. accuses Maduro and his wife of ordering kidnappings, beatings and murders, among other charges
item.description: Maduro’s wife is also accused of accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes in 2007.

item.title: ‘Everyone Is in Shock’: Swiss Town Grieves as More Fire Victims Are Identified
item.description: In Crans-Montana, the ski resort where at least 40 people died in a New Year’s Day blaze, residents were struggling to come to terms with one of the w...

item.title: Mamdani Names Dina Levy as NYC Housing Leader and Pledges ‘Rental Rip-off’ Hearings
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani named a housing commissioner and announced that the city would hold public hearings where frustrated renters could voice their co...

item.title: Satellite Imagery Reveals Damage to Venezuelan Base Where Maduro Was Captured
item.description: Before-and-after imagery released on Sunday shows that at least five buildings at the complex were destroyed by U.S. forces.

item.title: Exiled Venezuelans Celebrate Maduro’s Downfall, but Are Wary
item.description: “I had utterly lost hope,” said one Venezuelan who has lived in exile from his country for seven years.

item.title: Iran Faces Economic Challenges and Military Threats
item.description: Officials said that leaders were in survival mode amid anti-government protests and the prospect of again coming into the cross hairs of Israel and th...

item.title: Live Updates: As Venezuela Projects Defiance, Rubio Says U.S. Will Use ‘Leverage’ to Advance Its Interests
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said a military quarantine of Venezuela and its oil industry would remain in place. The death toll from the raid to sei...
